bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, September 7, 1922

div1.p: Hanson discusses financial matters and his feelings towards the International Health Board. He comments on Connor and Cumming.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, September 7, 1922
div1.opener:

HENRY HANSON
M. D.

FOUNDATION

Campaña Sanitaria contra la Fiebre Amarilla en el Perú

AVENIDA PIEROLA 545 - TELEFONO 3428
LIMA -- PERU
Yankton, S. D.
September ???7,1922,
NUMERO
____
My Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter of August the 17th was received
while we were in Sioux City. Just before coming west to South Dakota
I received two other letters from you which were forwarded to me fr
Peru, and I was very much interested in them even though we had talk-
ed to some extent about those matters in New York.

In regard to your money in Lima I wrote to the bank from N w
York confirming the instructions which I gave them before leaving
to convert your Peruvian pounds in to Dollars at the rate of 4:15 or
better. It will do no harm to write them and advise them to credit
the bank in New York or any other bank you may see fit to designate.
If you so prefer you can have them draw you a New York draft for the
amount and send you the draft direct which will enable you to cash
or deposit the money in any bank you like, and it will not be necessary
to take it up officially through the New York Bank unless you so pre-
fer/.

I am glad that the report on the fish proved of some value to
you. I have not yet been able to get busy on the rport which I want
to write as I have been travelling and will continue to travel until
about the first part of October. I do not understand Dr. Rose's atti-
tude in the matter. He impressed me as being rather indifferent about
a report on the work. Had I been in his place I should have insisted
on having a report, as I should have considered that an essential to
pass judgement on what had been done finally.

I do not think that I shall do any more for the I.H.B., I
shall feel quite content to have gotten through with this job in
Peru without any difficulty. There is something about the attitude
of the Office in New York which I do not understand and which has
given me the impression that the less I have to do with it the
better for my peace of mind. However as soon as I get to Baltimore
I shall talk to Dr. Welch as you suggest, advice from Welch or your-
self is about the best one can get.

About the African expedition Dr. Rose stated that they had de-
cided on Connor for the African expedition, and Wolcott to go as an
assistant or clinician. In that capacity Wolcott is away ahead of
M.E.C. in ability. MEC as far as I know has seen very little Y.F.
and I personally would not be any too ready to accept his clinical
diagnosis.

I have received a letter from one of my Secretaries of the Cam-
paign, and he speaks of my coming back as though they are still look-
ing for it down there. I do not think that Cardenas has much chance
if I really care to go back there. That however is a difficult prob-
lem to decide. It has very many attractive features, which practically
ofset the undesirable ones; however I will let that rest until later
in the year.

I had a very pleasant visit with the Surgeon General Cummins at
DIRECCION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN EL PERU
____
OFICINA CENTRAL
____
____
Dr. H.R. Carter, September 7, 1922.
Dr. Grubbs house on Staten Island. He seemed to ahev a very practical
way of looking at things, and I was favourably impressed with
him all the way thorugh.

You spoke of the length of the trip and the babies. They stood
it very well, and I am not sure that they were not happier enrout w
while they were living in the car than they have been after we have
commenced stopping and sort of establishing ourselves (temporarily
at least with our relatives)/ We are fast becoming Gypsified, and I
fear it would not take so very long to acquire a taste for this rov-
ing life. We have a new seven passenger Buick which was sufficiently
rooming to enable us to make improvised beds for the boies in the
back and they would lie down and take a nap when they began to feel
very tired. This was a special stunt on the part of Virgil. We had
two large very soft and cmfortable pillows and a couple of blankets
which he seemed to enjoy for his bed, and about two or three times
a day he would take a little nap while we were driving. On the whole
it was a very pleasant and comfortable trip.

Well this note is simply to acknowledge the receipt of you
letters, and in as much as I am on the road again I will not go into
any fuller discussion of plans or reports at the present time.

We lwave here tomorrow for Chamberlain South Dakota, ,a trip
of about 150 miles to the Northwest. We will remain there for about
two days when we will go from there to my sisters place in Hand
County, S.D., to near a small place called Vayland. There we will
only remain about two days when we will begin our return trip to
Sioux City by way of Brookings and Sioux Fallas in the state.
On the 17th or 18th we shall have to start our trip back to Wisc.
to take Karl to the St. John's Military Academy at Belafield, Wisc.

From tere we shall return to Sioux City for a short visit
and probably back here to Yankton again before I go on to Balti-
more where I am planning to put in the year in doing post Graduate
work and try for a Doctorate in Public Health.

With the very best wishes from us all to both Laura and
yourself.

Very sincerely yours, Henry Hanson Temporary address,
